sulphur: treat with sulphur in order to preserve; "These dried fruits are sulphured"

burst_in_on: spring suddenly; "He burst upon our conversation"
digress: lose clarity or turn aside especially from the main subject of attention or course of argument in writing, thinking, or speaking; "She always digresses when telling a story"; "her mind wanders"; "Don't digress when you give a lecture"
go_ahead: proceed (with a plan of action); "He went ahead with the project"
segue: proceed without interruption; in music or talk; "He segued into another discourse"
hook: take by theft; "Someone snitched my wallet!"
hit: cause to experience suddenly; "Panic struck me"; "An interesting idea hit her"; "A thought came to me"; "The thought struck terror in our minds"; "They were struck with fear"
quest: make a search (for); "Things that die with their eyes open and questing"; "The animal came questing through the forest"
entice: provoke someone to do something through (often false or exaggerated) promises or persuasion; "He lured me into temptation"
seduce: induce to have sex; "Harry finally seduced Sally"; "Did you score last night?"; "Harry made Sally"
lead_on: entice or induce especially when unwise or mistaken
pry: make an uninvited or presumptuous inquiry; "They pried the information out of him"
question: challenge the accuracy, probity, or propriety of; "We must question your judgment in this matter"

spy: catch sight of; to perceive with the eyes; "he caught sight of the king's men coming over the ridge"
investigate: investigate scientifically; "Let's investigate the syntax of Chinese"
quiz: examine someone's knowledge of something; "The teacher tests us every week"; "We got quizzed on French irregular verbs"
examine: observe, check out, and look over carefully or inspect; "The customs agent examined the baggage"; "I must see your passport before you can enter the country"
cross_examine: question closely, or question a witness that has already been questioned by the opposing side; "The witness was cross-examined by the defense"
pump: supply in great quantities; "Pump money into a project"
interrogate: transmit (a signal) for setting off an appropriate response, as in telecommunication
probe: examine physically with or as if with a probe; "probe an anthill"
re-examine: question after cross-examination by opposing counsel; "re-examine one's witness"
cell_phone: call up by using a cellular phone; "If the train is late, I will cell phone you"
call_in: take a player out of a game in order to exchange for another player
hang_on: hold the phone line open; "Please hang on while I get your folder"
telecommunicate: communicate over long distances, as via the telephone or e-mail
telex: communicate by telex; "We telexed the information to our sister company"
beep: call, summon, or alert with a beeper
call_back: return or repeat a telephone call; "I am busy right now--can you call back in an hour?"; "She left a message but the contractor never called back"
buzz: make a buzzing sound; "bees were buzzing around the hive"
convoke: call together; "The students were convened in the auditorium"
muster: gather or bring together; "muster the courage to do something"; "she rallied her intellect"; "Summon all your courage"
subpoena: serve or summon with a subpoena; "The witness and her records were subpoenaed"
invite: have as a guest; "I invited them to a restaurant"
provoke: evoke or provoke to appear or occur; "Her behavior provoked a quarrel between the couple"
jog: run for exercise; "jog along the canal"
call_on: have recourse to or make an appeal or request for help or information to; "She called on her Representative to help her"; "She turned to her relatives for help"
book_up: book all available places or tickets
reschedule: assign a new time and place for an event; "We had to reschedule the doctor's appointment"
reserve: arrange for and reserve (something for someone else) in advance; "reserve me a seat on a flight"; "The agent booked tickets to the show for the whole family"; "please hold a table at Maxim's"
forbid: command against; "I forbid you to call me late at night"; "Mother vetoed the trip to the chocolate store"; "Dad nixed our plans"
ban: forbid the public distribution of ( a movie or a newspaper)
bar: secure with, or as if with, bars; "He barred the door"
refuse: refuse to accept; "He refused my offer of hospitality"
contract_in: consent in writing to pay money to a trade union for political use
contract_out: assign a job to someone outside one's own business
rebuff: reject outright and bluntly; "She snubbed his proposal"
abjure: formally reject or disavow a formerly held belief, usually under pressure; "He retracted his earlier statements about his religion"; "She abjured her beliefs"
misstate: state something incorrectly; "You misstated my position"
retreat: move away, as for privacy; "The Pope retreats to Castelgondolfo every summer"
revoke: fail to follow suit when able and required to do so
renege: fail to fulfill a promise or obligation; "She backed out of her promise"
cancel: make up for; "His skills offset his opponent's superior strength"
cross_off: remove from a list; "Cross the name of the dead person off the list"
dismiss: stop associating with; "They dropped her after she had a child out of wedlock"
recount: count again; "We had to recount all the votes after an accusation of fraud was made"
pass_off: be accepted as something or somebody in a false character or identity; "She passed off as a Russian agent"
scoff: treat with contemptuous disregard; "flout the rules"
turn_a_blind_eye: refuse to acknowledge; "He turns a blind eye to the injustices in his office"
laugh_off: deal with a problem by laughing or pretending to be amused by it; "She laughs away all these problems"
permit: consent to, give permission; "She permitted her son to visit her estranged husband"; "I won't let the police search her basement"; "I cannot allow you to see your exam"
authorize: grant authorization or clearance for; "Clear the manuscript for publication"; "The rock star never authorized this slanderous biography"
assent: to agree or express agreement; "The Maestro assented to the request for an encore"
yield: give in, as to influence or pressure
clash: be incompatible; be or come into conflict; "These colors clash"
see_eye_to_eye: be in agreement; "We never saw eye to eye on this question"
concede: give over; surrender or relinquish to the physical control of another
subscribe: offer to buy, as of stocks and shares; "The broker subscribed 500 shares"
object: be averse to or express disapproval of; "My wife objects to modern furniture"
challenge: take exception to; "She challenged his claims"
counterchallenge: challenge in turn; "The authentication was counterchallenged"
interview: go for an interview in the hope of being hired; "The job candidate interviewed everywhere"
check_out: record, add up, and receive payment for items purchased; "She was checking out the apples that the customer had put on the conveyer belt"
miss: be absent; "The child had been missing for a week"
get_off: be relieved of one's duties temporarily
evade: practice evasion; "This man always hesitates and evades"
bypass: avoid something unpleasant or laborious; "You cannot bypass these rules!"
avoid: refrain from doing something; "She refrains from calling her therapist too often"; "He should avoid publishing his wife's memories"
keep_off: refrain from certain foods or beverages; "I keep off drugs"; "During Ramadan, Muslims avoid tobacco during the day"
shirk: avoid dealing with; "She shirks her duties"
shy_away_from: avoid having to deal with some unpleasant task; "I shy away from this task"
shun: avoid and stay away from deliberately; stay clear of
confront: be face to face with; "The child screamed when he confronted the man in the Halloween costume"
vex: subject to prolonged examination, discussion, or deliberation; "vex the subject of the death penalty"
wrestle: engage in a wrestling match; "The children wrestled in the garden"
bandy: toss or strike a ball back and forth
hash_out: speak with others about (something); talk (something) over in detail; have a discussion; "We discussed our household budget"
blaspheme: speak of in an irreverent or impious manner; "blaspheme God"
hold_forth: talk at length and formally about a topic; "The speaker dissertated about the social politics in 18th century England"
counter: speak in response; "He countered with some very persuasive arguments"
sass: answer back in an impudent or insolent manner; "don't sass me!"; "The teacher punished the students who were sassing all morning";
deny: refuse to grant, as of a petition or request; "The dean denied the students' request for more physics courses"; "the prisoners were denied the right to exercise for more than 2 hours a day"
admit: afford possibility; "This problem admits of no solution"; "This short story allows of several different interpretations"
make_no_bones_about: acknowledge freely and openly; "He makes no bones about the fact that he is gay"
make_a_clean_breast_of: admit or acknowledge a wrongdoing or error; "the writer of the anonymous letter owned up after they identified his handwriting"
bastardize: change something so that its value declines; for example, art forms
sustain: supply with necessities and support; "She alone sustained her family"; "The money will sustain our good cause"; "There's little to earn and many to keep"
confess: confess to a punishable or reprehensible deed, usually under pressure
stand_pat: refuse to abandon one's opinion or belief
hunker_down: take shelter; "During the sandstorm, they hunkered down in a small hut"
avow: admit openly and bluntly; make no bones about
disavow: refuse to acknowledge; disclaim knowledge of; responsibility for, or association with; "Her husband disavowed her after 30 years of marriage and six children"
attest: provide evidence for; stand as proof of; show by one's behavior, attitude, or external attributes; "His high fever attested to his illness"; "The buildings in Rome manifest a high level of architectural sophistication"; "This decision demonstrates his sense of fairness"
reflect: be bright by reflecting or casting light; "Drive carefully--the wet road reflects"
mirror: reflect as if in a mirror; "The smallest pond at night mirrors the firmament above"
notarize: authenticate as a notary; "We had to have the signature notarized"
certify: guarantee as meeting a certain standard; "certified grade AAA meat"
canonize: treat as a sacred person; "He canonizes women"
admonish: take to task; "He admonished the child for his bad behavior"
chastise: censure severely; "She chastised him for his insensitive remarks"
flame: be in flames or aflame; "The sky seemed to flame in the Hawaiian sunset"
call_on_the_carpet: censure severely or angrily; "The mother scolded the child for entering a stranger's car"; "The deputy ragged the Prime Minister"; "The customer dressed down the waiter for bringing cold soup"
represent: take the place of or be parallel or equivalent to; "Because of the sound changes in the course of history, an 'h' in Greek stands for an 's' in Latin"
tell_off: reprimand; "She told the misbehaving student off"
lip_off: speak spontaneously and without restraint; "She always shoots her mouth off and says things she later regrets"
reproach: express criticism towards; "The president reproached the general for his irresponsible behavior"
deplore: regret strongly; "I deplore this hostile action"; "we lamented the loss of benefits"
knock: rap with the knuckles; "knock on the door"
animadvert: express blame or censure or make a harshly critical remark
belabor: to work at or to absurd length; "belabor the obvious"
come_down: criticize or reprimand harshly; "The critics came down hard on the new play"
preach: deliver a sermon; "The minister is not preaching this Sunday"
sermonize: speak as if delivering a sermon; express moral judgements; "This man always sermonizes"
induct: admit as a member; "We were inducted into the honor society"
mentor: serve as a teacher or trusted counselor; "The famous professor mentored him during his years in graduate school"; "She is a fine lecturer but she doesn't like mentoring"
tutor: act as a guardian to someone
unteach: cause to unlearn; "teach somebody to unlearn old habits or methods"
ground: bring to the ground; "the storm grounded the ship"
lecture: deliver a lecture or talk; "She will talk at Rutgers next week"; "Did you ever lecture at Harvard?"
brief: give essential information to someone; "The reporters were briefed about the President's plan to invade"
debrief: put someone through a debriefing and make him report; "The released hostages were debriefed"
acquaint: inform; "Please acquaint your colleagues of your plans to move"
warn: admonish or counsel in terms of someone's behavior; "I warned him not to go too far"; "I warn you against false assumptions"; "She warned him to be quiet"
fill_in: supply with information on a specific topic; "He filled me in on the latest developments"
misinform: give false or misleading information to
lie: be and remain in a particular state or condition; "lie dormant"
perjure: knowingly tell an untruth in a legal court and render oneself guilty of perjury
suborn: incite to commit a crime or an evil deed; "He suborned his butler to cover up the murder of his wife"
fib: tell a relatively insignificant lie; "Fibbing is not acceptable, even if you don't call it lying"
beat_around_the_bush: be deliberately ambiguous or unclear in order to mislead or withhold information
typify: embody the essential characteristics of or be a typical example of; "The fugue typifies Bach's style of composition"
misrepresent: represent falsely; "This statement misrepresents my intentions"
tinge: affect as in thought or feeling; "My personal feelings color my judgment in this case"; "The sadness tinged his life"
pose: behave affectedly or unnaturally in order to impress others; "Don't pay any attention to him--he is always posing to impress his peers!"; "She postured and made a total fool of herself"
bluff: deceive an opponent by a bold bet on an inferior hand with the result that the opponent withdraws a winning hand
feign: make believe with the intent to deceive; "He feigned that he was ill"; "He shammed a headache"
go_through_the_motions: pretend to do something by acting as if one was really doing it; "She isn't really working--she's just going through the motions"
take_a_dive: pretend to be knocked out, as of a boxer
bamboozle: conceal one's true motives from especially by elaborately feigning good intentions so as to gain an end; "He bamboozled his professors into thinking that he knew the subject well"
overstate: to enlarge beyond bounds or the truth; "tended to romanticize and exaggerate this `gracious Old South' imagery"
soft-pedal: play down or obscure; "His advisers soft-pedaled the president's blunder"
trivialize: make trivial or insignificant; "Don't trivialize the seriousness of the issue!"
overemphasize: place special or excessive emphasis on; "I cannot overemphasize the importance of this book"
re-emphasise: emphasize anew; "The director re-emphasized the need for greater productivity"
understate: represent as less significant or important
denounce: announce the termination of, as of treaties
accuse: bring an accusation against; level a charge against; "The neighbors accused the man of spousal abuse"
arraign: call before a court to answer an indictment
tax: set or determine the amount of (a payment such as a fine)
complain: express complaints, discontent, displeasure, or unhappiness; "My mother complains all day"; "She has a lot to kick about"
recriminate: return an accusation against someone or engage in mutual accusations; charge in return
impeach: challenge the honesty or veracity of; "the lawyers tried to impeach the credibility of the witnesses"
claw: move as if by clawing, seizing, or digging; "They clawed their way to the top of the mountain"

nitpick: be overly critical; criticize minor details
pan: make a sweeping movement; "The camera panned across the room"
defame: charge falsely or with malicious intent; attack the good name and reputation of someone; "The journalists have defamed me!" "The article in the paper sullied my reputation"
assassinate: murder; especially of socially prominent persons; "Anwar Sadat was assassinated because many people did not like his peace politics with Israel"
libel: print slanderous statements against; "The newspaper was accused of libeling him"
vilify: spread negative information about; "The Nazi propaganda vilified the Jews"
badmouth: speak unfavorably about; "She badmouths her husband everywhere"
diss: treat, mention, or speak to rudely; "He insulted her with his rude remarks"; "the student who had betrayed his classmate was dissed by everyone"
bristle_at: show anger or indignation; "She bristled at his insolent remarks"
mock: imitate with mockery and derision; "The children mocked their handicapped classmate"
caricature: represent in or produce a caricature of; "The drawing caricatured the President"
impersonate: assume or act the character of; "She impersonates Madonna"; "The actor portrays an elderly, lonely man"

jeer: laugh at with contempt and derision; "The crowd jeered at the speaker"
pull_the_leg_of: tell false information to for fun; "Are you pulling my leg?"
incite: provoke or stir up; "incite a riot"; "set off great unrest among the people"
ridicule: subject to laughter or ridicule; "The satirists ridiculed the plans for a new opera house"; "The students poked fun at the inexperienced teacher"; "His former students roasted the professor at his 60th birthday"

horse_around: indulge in horseplay; "Enough horsing around--let's get back to work!"; "The bored children were fooling about"
deceive: be false to; be dishonest with
kid: be silly or tease one another; "After we relaxed, we just kidded around"
referee: be a referee or umpire in a sports competition
condemn: compel or force into a particular state or activity; "His devotion to his sick wife condemned him to a lonely existence"
praise: express approval of; "The parents praised their children for their academic performance"
salute: become noticeable; "a terrible stench saluted our nostrils"
crow: utter shrill sounds; "The cocks crowed all morning"
trumpet: play or blow on the trumpet
exuberate: to express great joy; "Who cannot exult in Spring?"
cheerlead: act as a cheerleader in a sports event
amuse: occupy in an agreeable, entertaining or pleasant fashion; "The play amused the ladies"
applaud: clap one's hands or shout after performances to indicate approval
laud: praise, glorify, or honor; "extol the virtues of one's children"; "glorify one's spouse's cooking"
ensky: exalt to the skies; lift to the skies or to heaven with praise
promulgate: put a law into effect by formal declaration
acclaim: praise vociferously; "The critics hailed the young pianist as a new Rubinstein"
boo: show displeasure, as after a performance or speech
vitriol: expose to the effects of vitriol or injure with vitriol
rip: move precipitously or violently; "The tornado ripped along the coast"
accurse: curse or declare to be evil or anathema or threaten with divine punishment
blog: read, write, or edit a shared on-line journal
curse: heap obscenities upon; "The taxi driver who felt he didn't get a high enough tip cursed the passenger"
gee: turn to the right side; "the horse geed"

desecrate: violate the sacred character of a place or language; "desecrate a cemetery"; "violate the sanctity of the church"; "profane the name of God"

call_out: call out loudly, as of names or numbers
contest: to make the subject of dispute, contention, or litigation; "They contested the outcome of the race"

threaten: to be a menacing indication of something:"The clouds threaten rain"; "Danger threatens"

rede: give an interpretation or explanation to

advise: inform (somebody) of something; "I advised him that the rent was due"
familiarize: make familiar or conversant with; "you should acquaint yourself with your new computer"; "We familiarized ourselves with the new surroundings"

verse: compose verses or put into verse; "He versified the ancient saga"
reacquaint: familiarize anew; "We reacquainted ourselves with this technique"
propose: ask (someone) to marry you; "he popped the question on Sunday night"; "she proposed marriage to the man she had known for only two months"; "The old bachelor finally declared himself to the young woman"
proposition: suggest sex to; "She was propositioned by a stranger at the party"
feed_back: submit (information) again to a program or automatic system
propound: put forward, as of an idea
consult: get or ask advice from; "Consult your local broker"; "They had to consult before arriving at a decision"

submit: yield to the control of another
return: return in kind; "return a compliment"; "return her love"

stroke: touch lightly and repeatedly, as with brushing motions; "He stroked his long beard"

curry_favor: seek favor by fawning or flattery; "This employee is currying favor with his superordinates"
butter_up: flatter with the intention of getting something
rave: participate in an all-night techno dance party
commend: present as worthy of regard, kindness, or confidence; "His paintings commend him to the artistic world"
speak_of_the_devil: mention someone's name who just then appears
gloat: gaze at or think about something with great self-satisfaction, gratification, or joy
promise: give grounds for expectations; "The new results were promising"; "The results promised fame and glory"

swear_off: promise to abstain from; "I have sworn off cigarettes altogether"
article: bind by a contract; especially for a training period
oblige: provide a service or favor for someone; "We had to oblige him"

tie_down: secure with or as if with ropes; "tie down the prisoners"; "tie up the old newspapers and bring them to the recycling shed"

vow: dedicate to a deity by a vow
inscribe: draw within a figure so as to touch in as many places as possible
rededicate: dedicate anew; "They were asked to rededicate themselves to their country"
take_the_veil: become a nun; "The young woman took the veil after her fiance died"
stipulate: give a guarantee or promise of; "They stipulated to release all the prisoners"

swear: make a deposition; declare under oath
guarantee: stand behind and guarantee the quality, accuracy, or condition of; "The dealer warrants all the cars he sells"; "I warrant this information"
doom: make certain of the failure or destruction of; "This decision will doom me to lose my position"

apologize: defend, explain, clear away, or make excuses for by reasoning; "rationalize the child's seemingly crazy behavior"; "he rationalized his lack of success"
excuse: accept an excuse for; "Please excuse my dirty hands"
alibi: exonerate by means of an alibi
frank: exempt by means of an official pass or letter, as from customs or other checks
defend: be the defense counsel for someone in a trial; "Ms. Smith will represent the defendant"
stand_up: resist or withstand wear, criticism, etc.; "Her shoes won't hold up"; "This theory won't hold water"

cross_oneself: make the sign of the cross; in the Catholic religion
bow: bend the head or the upper part of the body in a gesture of respect or greeting; "He bowed before the King"
congee: depart after obtaining formal permission; "He has congeed with the King"
take_a_bow: acknowledge praise or accept credit; "They finally took a bow for what they did"
curtsy: bend the knees in a gesture of respectful greeting
hail: precipitate as small ice particles; "It hailed for an hour"
reintroduce: introduce anew; "We haven't met in a long time, so let me reintroduce myself"
precede: come before; "Most English adjectives precede the noun they modify"

absolve: let off the hook; "I absolve you from this responsibility"
meld: announce for a score; of cards in a card game

amnesty: grant a pardon to (a group of people)
extenuate: lessen or to try to lessen the seriousness or extent of; "The circumstances extenuate the crime"

heckle: comb with a heckle; "heckle hemp or flax"

foster: promote the growth of; "Foster our children's well-being and education"
patronize: do one's shopping at; do business with; be a customer or client of
murmur: speak softly or indistinctly; "She murmured softly to the baby in her arms"
grouch: show one's unhappiness or critical attitude; "He scolded about anything that he thought was wrong"; "We grumbled about the increased work load"
coo: speak softly or lovingly; "The mother who held her baby was cooing softly"

raise_hell: take strong and forceful action, as to object or express discontent; "She raised hell when she found out that she wold not be hired again"
rail: enclose with rails; "rail in the old graves"
regret: feel sad about the loss or absence of
exclaim: utter aloud; often with surprise, horror, or joy; "`I won!' he exclaimed"; "`Help!' she cried"; "`I'm here,' the mother shouted when she saw her child looking lost"
shout: utter a sudden loud cry; "she cried with pain when the doctor inserted the needle"; "I yelled to her from the window but she couldn't hear me"

interject: to insert between other elements; "She interjected clever remarks"
vociferate: utter in a very loud voice; "They vociferated their demands"
holler: shout out; "He hollered out to surrender our weapons"
thunder: be the case that thunder is being heard; "Whenever it thunders, my dog crawls under the bed"

predict: make a prediction about; tell in advance; "Call the outcome of an election"

bet: stake on the outcome of an issue; "I bet $100 on that new horse"; "She played all her money on the dark horse"
redetermine: fix, find, or establish again; "the physicists redetermined Planck's constant"

suspect: hold in suspicion; believe to be guilty; "The U.S. suspected Bin Laden as the mastermind behind the terrorist attacks"
bespeak: be a signal for or a symptom of; "These symptoms indicate a serious illness"; "Her behavior points to a severe neurosis"; "The economic indicators signal that the euro is undervalued"

fly_in_the_face_of: go against; "This action flies in the face of the agreement"
exceed: be greater in scope or size than some standard; "Their loyalty exceeds their national bonds"
suffice: be sufficient; be adequate, either in quality or quantity; "A few words would answer"; "This car suits my purpose well"; "Will $100 do?"; "A 'B' grade doesn't suffice to get me into medical school"; "Nothing else will serve"
go_a_long_way: suffice or be adequate for a while or to a certain extent
act_as: function as or act like; "This heap of stones will act as a barrier"
fall_short_of: fail to satisfy, as of expectations, for example
stink: be extremely bad in quality or in one's performance; "This term paper stinks!"
shine_at: be good at; "She shines at math"
ape: imitate uncritically and in every aspect; "Her little brother apes her behavior"
echo: call to mind; "His words echoed John F. Kennedy"
follow_suit: do what someone else is doing
focus_on: center upon; "Her entire attention centered on her children"; "Our day revolved around our work"
implicate: bring into intimate and incriminating connection; "He is implicated in the scheme to defraud the government"
embroil: force into some kind of situation, condition, or course of action; "They were swept up by the events"; "don't drag me into this business"
disinvolve: free from involvement or entanglement; "How can I disentangle myself from her personal affairs?"
concern: be on the mind of; "I worry about the second Germanic consonant shift"
matter_to: be of importance or consequence; "This matters to me!"
intrigue: cause to be interested or curious
discontinue: come to or be at an end; "the support from our sponsoring agency will discontinue after March 31"
call_it_quits: stop doing what one is doing; "At midnight, the student decided to call it quits and closed his books"
distance: keep at a distance; "we have to distance ourselves from these events in order to continue living"
housekeep: maintain a household; take care of all business related to a household
ramble_on: continue talking or writing in a desultory manner; "This novel rambles on and jogs"
beard: go along the rim, like a beard around the chin; "Houses bearded the top of the heights"
enfilade: rake or be in a position to rake with gunfire in a lengthwise direction
imbricate: place so as to overlap; "imbricate the roof tiles"
mediate: occupy an intermediate or middle position or form a connecting link or stage between two others; "mediate between the old and the new"
subtend: be opposite to; of angles and sides, in geometry
flank: be located at the sides of something or somebody
surmount: be on top of; "The scarf surmounted the gown"
radiolocate: locate by means of radar; "The pilot managed to radiolocate the lost aircraft"
endanger: pose a threat to; present a danger to; "The pollution is endangering the crops"
embody: represent or express something abstract in tangible form; "This painting embodies the feelings of the Romantic period"
characterize: be characteristic of; "What characterizes a Venetian painting?"
body: invest with or as with a body; give body to
befit: accord or comport with; "This kind of behavior does not suit a young woman!"
suit: be agreeable or acceptable; "This time suits me"
verge: border on; come close to; "His behavior verges on the criminal"
border_on: come near or verge on, resemble, come nearer in quality, or character; "This borders on discrimination!"; "His playing approaches that of Horowitz"
last: persist for a specified period of time; "The bad weather lasted for three days"
outwear: last longer than others; "This material outwears all others"
inhere_in: be part of; "This problem inheres in the design"
fall_into: be included in or classified as; "This falls under the rubric 'various'"
shimmer: shine with a weak or fitful light; "Beech leaves shimmered in the moonlight"
lend_oneself: be applicable to; as to an analysis; "This theory lends itself well to our new data"
piddle: waste time; spend one's time idly or inefficiently
honeymoon: spend a holiday after one's marriage; "they plan to honeymoon in Hawai'i"
while_away: spend or pass, as with boredom or in a pleasant manner; of time
sojourn: spend a certain length of time; reside temporarily
winter: spend the winter; "We wintered on the Riviera"; "Shackleton's men overwintered on Elephant Island"
summer: spend the summer; "We summered in Kashmir"
breast: meet at breast level; "The runner breasted the tape"
bound: form the boundary of; be contiguous to
shore: serve as a shore to; "The river was shored by trees"
embank: enclose with banks, as for support or protection; "The river was embanked with a dyke"
box_in: enclose or confine as if in a box
pattern: form a pattern; "These sentences pattern like the ones we studied before"
stick_out: extend out or project in space; "His sharp nose jutted out"; "A single rock sticks out from the cliff"
protuberate: cause to bulge out or project
teem: be teeming, be abuzz; "The garden was swarming with bees"; "The plaza is teeming with undercover policemen"; "her mind pullulated with worries"
abound: be in a state of movement or action; "The room abounded with screaming children"; "The garden bristled with toddlers"
attach_to: be present or associated with an event or entity; "French fries come with the hamburger"; "heart attacks are accompanied by distruction of heart tissue"; "fish usually goes with white wine"; "this kind of vein accompanies certain arteries"
droop: hang loosely or laxly; "His tongue lolled"
gape: be wide open; "the deep gaping canyon"
sulk: be in a huff and display one's displeasure; "She is pouting because she didn't get what she wanted"
take_kindly_to: be willing or inclined to accept; "He did not take kindly to my critical remarks"
belong_to: be a part or adjunct; "the uniform looks like it belonged to a museum collection"; "These pages don't belong"
incur: make oneself subject to; bring upon oneself; become liable to; "People who smoke incur a great danger to their health"
look_out_on: be oriented in a certain direction; "The house looks out on a tennis court"; "The apartment overlooks the Hudson"
center_on: have as a center; "The region centers on Charleston"
do_well: act in one's own or everybody's best interest; "You will do well to arrive on time tomorrow!"
go_back: belong to an earlier time; "This story dates back 200 years"
rut: be in a state of sexual excitement; of male mammals
stagnate: stand still; "Industry will stagnate if we do not stimulate our economy"
come_in_handy: be useful for a certain purpose
refrain: resist doing something; "He refrained from hitting him back"; "she could not forbear weeping"
forbear: refrain from doing; "she forbore a snicker"
help_oneself: abstain from doing; always used with a negative; "I can't help myself--I have to smoke"; "She could not help watching the sad spectacle"
hoodoo: bring bad luck; be a source of misfortune
impend: be imminent or about to happen; "Changes are impending"
come_in_for: be subject to or the object of; "The governor came in for a lot of criticism"
persist: stay behind; "The smell stayed in the room"; "The hostility remained long after they made up"
resplend: be resplendent or radiant; to shine brightly; "The Queen's garments resplended in velvet and jewels"
go_far: extend in importance or range; "His accomplishments go far"
iridesce: be iridescent; "The corals iridesced under the surface of the clear water"
opalesce: reflect light or colors like an opal; "Distant clouds opalesce like pale brocade"; "raindrops caught in a sunbeam seem to opalesce"
tie_in: be in connection with something relevant; "This ties in closely with his earlier remarks"
go_into: be used or required for; "A lot of energy went into the organization of this banquet"
let_go: be relaxed; "Don't be so worried all the time--just let go!"
circumvolute: wind or turn in volutions, especially in an inward spiral, as of snail
spiral: form a spiral; "The path spirals up the mountain"
miscegenate: marry or cohabit with a person of another race
issue_forth: come forth; "A scream came from the woman's mouth"; "His breath came hard"
ornament: be an ornament to; "stars ornamented the Christmas tree"
assonate: correspond in vowel sounds; rhyme in assonance; "The accented vowels assonated in this poem"
osculate: be intermediate between two taxonomic groups; "These species osculate"
summarize: be a summary of; "The abstract summarizes the main ideas in the paper"
cohere: cause to form a united, orderly, and aesthetically consistent whole; "Religion can cohere social groups"
cash_out: choose a simpler life style after questioning personal and career satisfaction goals; "After 3 decades in politics, she cashed out and moved to Polynesia"
base: situate as a center of operations; "we will base this project in the new lab"
rain: precipitate as rain; "If it rains much more, we can expect some flooding"
ice_up: become covered with a layer of ice; of a surface such as a window; "When the wings iced up, the pilot was forced to land his plane"
snow: fall as snow; "It was snowing all night"
sleet: precipitate as a mixture of rain and snow; "If the temperature rises above freezing, it will probably sleet"
ignite: cause to start burning; subject to fire or great heat; "Great heat can ignite almost any dry matter"; "Light a cigarette"
set_ablaze: set fire to; cause to start burning; "Lightening set fire to the forest"
reignite: ignite anew, as of something burning; "The strong winds reignited the cooling embers"
kindle: catch fire; "The dried grass of the prairie kindled, spreading the flames for miles"
flare: shine with a sudden light; "The night sky flared with the massive bombardment"
flare_up: ignite quickly and suddenly, especially after having died down; "the fire flared up and died down once again"
twinkle: emit or reflect light in a flickering manner; "Does a constellation twinkle more brightly than a single star?"
luminesce: be or become luminescent; exhibit luminescence
spark: emit or produce sparks; "A high tension wire, brought down by a storm, can continue to spark"
ray: emit as rays; "That tower rays a laser beam for miles across the sky"
bluster: blow hard; be gusty, as of wind; "A southeaster blustered onshore"; "The flames blustered"
overcloud: become covered with clouds; "The sky clouded over"
clear_up: become clear; "The sky cleared after the storm"
blight: cause to suffer a blight; "Too much rain may blight the garden with mold"
swamp: drench or submerge or be drenched or submerged; "The tsunami swamped every boat in the harbor"
run_dry: become empty of water; "The river runs dry in the summer"
